title: Scottish cyclist to attempt record for furthest distance cycled in a week
content:
Will Strickson
21 Apr 2021

Endurance cyclist Josh Quigley will attempt to cyclist over 2,177 miles from 26th April and hopes to raise £10,000 for Arthritis Action

Scottish endurance cyclist Josh Quigley is to attempt to break the Guinness World Record for the greatest distance cycled in a week (unpaced) to raise money for Arthritis Action.

Quigley, who had previously set the North Coast 500 record in September just nine months after almost losing his life on a round-the-world challenge when he was struck by a car at 70mph, will try to cycle an average of 320 miles per day around an 80-mile route between Aberdeen and the Cairngorms between 26th April and 3rd May.

Though only 28, he is now facing a second major comeback challenge having broken his arm, shoulder, collarbone, pelvis, spine, pubic bone and four ribs on a training ride in Dubai just three months ago.

He was also diagnosed with arthritis earlier this year and hopes his record attempt (and hopeful success) will inspire the 10 million people in the UK impacted by the condition.

He said of this new challenge, 'When I set the record for the North Coast 500 just nine months after being hit by a car at 70mph, I thought I had my comeback story done and dusted.

'I never imagined that just 12 months after that life-threatening accident in America, I would find myself hospitalised again after a 40mph crash while winter training in Dubai.

'To bounce back from a major accident and set a record once is a great story. But to do it twice in the space of 18 months and get my first Guinness World Record? That will be pretty special, and that is exactly what I plan on doing.'

To find out more about Quigley visit joshquigley92.com and to donate to his fundraiser visit justgiving.com/fundraising/joshquigley7daycyclingworldrecord
